title: (x) Generic Slab Font needed to be Identified - Berthold Baskerville {Nina}
content:
I know I've seen this one a million times but just can pin it.. any help?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20120203233407im_/http:/typophile.com/files/debra033_4305.jpg)
author: Mac_Ink

comments.content: ah! I think youre right. I've been searching there for a 1/2hr. Thanks much!

You're welcome. BTW, [WhatTheFont](http://web.archive.org/web/20120203233407/http:/new.myfonts.com/WhatTheFont/) gets pretty close for this.  
The [BE version](http://web.archive.org/web/20120203233407/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/berthold/baskerville-be/) is quite similar too, but the BQ has the inktraps, and looking at your "M" that's probably a closer match. There might be other versions, but I think the general direction is right. :)
The BE version is exactly it, the R and D are identical. Nice work!

I'm surprised to learn that the BE and BQ versions of Berthold fonts are different. What's the reason for two abbreviations? Was one of them the Adobe/Berthold version?

- Mike Yanega

I don't know what "BE" and "BQ" means actually, I was just lookin' at the pictures. :)  
I was sorta hoping for someone to explain.

@Mike, Nina: BQ = Berthold Quality, BE = Berthold Exklusiv, whatever that means. Also see the [FAQ at bertholdtypes.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20120203233407/http:/www.bertholdtypes.com/info/FAQ.html#6). It’s a mess. This place apparently isn’t run by type users, let alone designers.
